headline: CNN Special Reports
subHeadline: CNN Special Report: Supreme Power: Inside the Highest Court in the Land. Aired 10-11a ET

utterances.speaker: ANNOUNCER
utterances.sentences: The following is a CNN Special Report.

utterances.speaker: FAREED ZAKARIA, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: May 2nd of this year, an idyllic spring morning, no hint of what is to come that night. The nine justices of the Supreme Court attend a memorial service for one of their own, the late John Paul Stevens. The end of the court's term is just weeks away.

utterances.speaker: JIM SCIUTTO, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: A whole host of consequential decisions to come.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: A bitterly divided country awaits a momentous decision.

utterances.speaker: JAKE TAPPER, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Is this the end of Roe v. Wade?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Of law and of life.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: At the services, the judges look collegial. They call themselves as happy family. Beneath the surface, there is much more to this story.

utterances.speaker: NINA TOTENBERG, NPR LEGAL AFFAIR CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: They not only aren't getting along with each other. They don't like each other.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED PROTESTERS
utterances.sentences: You don't care if people die.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: It is a court at war with itself.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED PROTESTERS
utterances.sentences: It's a lie.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And in the center stands Chief Justice John Roberts.

utterances.speaker: JOAN BISKUPIC, CNN SENIOR SUPREME COURT ANALYST
utterances.sentences: John Roberts is someone who is used to winning.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: He's very much a judicial conservative.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: Not a fan of Roe vs. Wade.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But the chief is said to be keenly aware that abolishing Roe could tear America apart.

utterances.speaker: NOAH FELDMAN, HARVARD LAW SCHOOL
utterances.sentences: He cared more about preserving the legitimacy of the Supreme Court.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Which meant saving Roe.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED PROTESTERS
utterances.sentences: Abort the court.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: He wasn't going to let go.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED PROTESTERS
utterances.sentences: Abortion bans have got to go.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Months earlier.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED PROTESTER
utterances.sentences: Abortion justice.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Oral arguments in the case of "Dobbs versus Jackson Women's Health Center." At issue, a Mississippi law that would limit but not eliminate the right to an abortion but five justices want to abolish it all together.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: The conservatives to his right wanted to go all out against Roe v. Wade.JUSTICE SAMUEL ALITO, U.S. SUPREME COURT: The fetus has an interest in having a life.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: I thought it was stunning.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: To save Roe, Roberts must change one vote.

utterances.speaker: FELDMAN
utterances.sentences: There was really only one desperate hope but all came down to Kavanaugh.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Justice Brett Kavanaugh.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: Brett Kavanaugh has at times gone with the chief.

utterances.speaker: FELDMAN
utterances.sentences: Prior to his confirmation hearings, Justice Kavanaugh was widely thought of as somebody who likes to be in the middle.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: That was prior to the hearings.SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R-SC): I hope the American people can see through this sham.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The fight over Kavanaugh's nomination was ugly.

utterances.speaker: WOLF BLITZER, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: A nomination in turmoil.JUSTICE BRETT KAVANAUGH, U.S. SUPREME COURT: This has destroyed my family.

utterances.speaker: BLITZER
utterances.sentences: Physical and sexual assault.

utterances.speaker: KAVANAUGH
utterances.sentences: I've never sexually assaulted anyone.

utterances.speaker: TOTENBERG
utterances.sentences: It was just a train wreck.

utterances.speaker: KAVANAUGH
utterances.sentences: So help me God.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Some even thought that damaging hearings might affect Kavanaugh's vote on Roe.

utterances.speaker: FELDMAN
utterances.sentences: He would have enraged conservatives by not overturning Roe v. Wade. Right now those are his only friends.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Yet as the spring wore on, there appeared to be a chance Kavanaugh might flip.

utterances.speaker: FELDMAN
utterances.sentences: A lot of chatter in conservative circles he might be about to go along with Chief Justice Roberts.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Then the stakes rose higher. In late April, the "Wall Street Journal" fired a warning shot straight at Roberts and Kavanaugh.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: The "Wall Street Journal" editorial page was very wired into the conservative side of this court.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: It called the Roberts' effort to save Roe a ferocious lobbying campaign.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: Don't be bullied. Don't be persuaded by John Roberts.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Yet even by May 2nd, there was still a chance of turning the vote around.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: I thought there might be some ambivalence there.

utterances.speaker: FELDMAN
utterances.sentences: Chief Justice Roberts bent over backwards.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But the chief's desperate mission would not last the night.

utterances.speaker: JOHN BERMAN, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: The stunning news from the Supreme Court.

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Unprecedented leak of this major draft opinion.

utterances.speaker: TOTENBERG
utterances.sentences: It was like a bomb went off.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: It was such a breach of their secrecy.ZAKARIA (on-camera): First time in history.

utterances.speaker: TOTENBERG
utterances.sentences: There has never been a leak like this.ZAKARIA (voice-over): John Roberts had lost his fight.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED PROTESTERS
utterances.sentences: My body, my choice. UNIDENTIFIED PROTESTERS

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: June 24th, the final decision. A shock but not a surprise.

utterances.speaker: ANNOUNCER
utterances.sentences: This is CNN Breaking News.

utterances.speaker: JESSICA SCHNEIDER, CNN JUSTICE CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: The Supreme Court has overturned Roe v. Wade.

utterances.speaker: ALISYN CAMEROTA, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: And ended the constitutional right to an abortion.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: There was unbridled joy.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: This is a historic day.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED PROTESTER
utterances.sentences: Ho, ho, Roe v. Wade has got to go.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: On the other side of the great American divide, the deepest despair.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I am absolutely terrified. I'm so beyond livid.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED PROTESTERS
utterances.sentences: My body, my choice.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED PROTESTERS
utterances.sentences: No justice, no peace.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: Everything is on the table now. Everything is on the table.ZAKARIA (on-camera): I'm Fareed Zakaria. The republic endures and this is the symbol of its faith. That description of the Supreme Court came from Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes in 1932. His words eloquent and precisely right. This country has long seen its highest court as the pinnacle of democracy. America's greatest glory has been judicial independence. Judges who stood apart from politics trusted to make big decisions based solely on the law. Now, that foundational idea, that faith, may be just one more casualty of America's deep political divide. 75 percent of Americans, three quarters, tell Gallup they do not have full confidence in the Supreme Court. It is the lowest number ever recorded. Why? What happened? This is the story of how we got here.

utterances.speaker: FELDMAN
utterances.sentences: The current Supreme Court committed an act of institutional suicide.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED PROTESTERS
utterances.sentences: Burn it down.

utterances.speaker: FELDMAN
utterances.sentences: By overturning Roe v. Wade.ZAKARIA (voice-over): After the most dramatic Supreme Court ruling in decades, there was rage. Even violence. Americans had a message for their highest court. UNIDENTIFIED PROTESTERS: We won't go back.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Across the country, tens of thousands took to the streets.REP. MAXINE WATERS (D-CA): You ain't seen nothing yet.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The constitutional scholar Noah Feldman says America now sees a court poisoned by politics.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED PROTESTERS
utterances.sentences: (EXPLETIVE DELETED) the Supreme Court.

utterances.speaker: FELDMAN
utterances.sentences: The current court is taking all of its weight and putting it behind popular conservative positions, and the reason that's so scary from the standpoint of the United States is that we don't have another institution whose job it is to protect the most vulnerable, to protect the rule of law.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Feldman is a liberal.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: So help you God.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Who testified in favor of Donald Trump's impeachment.

utterances.speaker: FELDMAN
utterances.sentences: President Trump has committed impeachable high crimes and misdemeanors.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Yet he also supported the nomination of Amy Coney Barrett.

utterances.speaker: FELDMAN
utterances.sentences: She is a first class lawyer. I believe we need the smartest and best people. The right way to think about the Supreme Court is not to ask, is it liberal? Is it conservative? It's to ask what is the role that it fundamentally plays in preserving constitutional governance?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED PROTESTERS
utterances.sentences: We the people.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Many Americans question that role.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: These are live images, folks, at the doors of the Supreme Court.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: This crowd was trying to force its way inside the court to stop the swearing in of Justice Brett Kavanaugh.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: There's an adage about what the Supreme Court has. It doesn't have the power of the purse. It doesn't have the power of the sword. What it has is public respect.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: As a reporter, Joan Biskupic has seen radical changes over her 30 years of watching the court.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: People believe that the Dobbs ruling was politically motivated and why would they not? Former President Donald Trump ran on a platform that included appointing only justices who would reverse Roe v. Wade.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, FORMER PRESIDENT
utterances.sentences: I will appoint judges that will be pro-life, yes. Highly, highly respected judges.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Republicans were nervous that Trump would not appoint true conservatives.SEN. TED CRUZ (R-TX): He will not invest the capital to confirm a conservative.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: To mollify the right, he released a list of right-wing judges.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: What we did, and I just have it, we just took a list of judges --

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: Can he deliver the kinds of candidates we want for the Supreme Court? When he releases that, it immediately gives him credibility among establishment Republicans.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But Donald Trump had nothing to do with choosing the names on his list.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: That list was of course generated primarily by the Federalist Society.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The Federalist Society, the most powerful legal conservative group in the country. Every one of the conservative justices has strong ties to it.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: I thought it was stunning. The presidential candidate would take a list of judges from the Federalist Society and use those judges as part of a campaign?

utterances.speaker: JIM ACOSTA, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: So we'll see the president and the Supreme Court justice.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The president who chose three Supreme Court justices.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Congratulations.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Who transformed the court for a generation, outsourced crucial decisions to this man.LEONARD LEO, CO-CHAIRMAN, THE FEDERALIST SOCIETY: He had an idea. What do you think of having me put out a list of people who I would pick from for the U.S. Supreme Court? I said about to suggest to him names of people who would be appropriate.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Leonard Leo has long been the power behind the Federalist Society. Amassing hundreds of millions of dollars to nurture a network of conservative judges.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: $1.6 billion from just one donor. ZAKARIAdonation for another conservative group he controls.

utterances.speaker: ROSEMARY CHURCH, CNN INTERNATIONAL ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: The largest single donor contribution that's ever been reported.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Leo told "The Washington Post" he doesn't like to talk about money.

utterances.speaker: LEO
utterances.sentences: I don't engage in that conversation because, one, I'm not particularly knowledgeable about a lot of it but secondly because it's just not what I do.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: All of this is important because Leonard Leo, a man elected by no one, a man few Americans have even heard of, played a powerful role in choosing the most conservative court in a century.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Here they come.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: One example of Leo's clout, Justice Neil Gorsuch.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Was this the choice you advised President Trump to make?

utterances.speaker: LEO
utterances.sentences: Well, my job was just to give him a list of great people and to tell him everything I could about each of them. I was ultimately his decision.

utterances.speaker: MIKA BRZEZINSKI, MSNBC ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Was he on the list?

utterances.speaker: LEO
utterances.sentences: Neil Gorsuch?

utterances.speaker: BRZEZINSKI
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEO
utterances.sentences: Yes, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: And Leonard, you are fantastic.

utterances.speaker: CARRIE SEVERINO, PRESIDENT, JUDICIAL CRISIS NETWORK
utterances.sentences: The ability of Trump to have that outstanding list of nominees to choose from has everything to do with the success of the Federalist Society in creating a movement.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Carrie Severino works with Leonard Leo.

utterances.speaker: SEVERINO
utterances.sentences: He's someone I absolutely work with very closely.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: She has led the public relations fight to push through conservative nominees.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Never a whisper of misconduct. It doesn't add up. Confirm Kavanaugh.

utterances.speaker: SEVERINO
utterances.sentences: What we're really seeing is the left losing that stranglehold on the court and being very frustrated that there are Republican nominees who aren't as easily swayed to the middle as they were before.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The Federalist Society began back in 1982 with a few chapters on law school campuses.

utterances.speaker: FELDMAN
utterances.sentences: The Federalist Society was born out of a perception by conservatives and that liberal constitutional ideas had become the main stream within American legal thinking.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Which was true, so conservatives embraced the society.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: Very moneyed interest are pouring funds into the Federalist Society.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Then in 1987 a seismic event turned the Federalist Society into a conservative juggernaut. Ronald Reagan nominated one of its founding member to the Supreme Court, Judge Robert Bork.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: The Bork battle was such a big defining moment in America.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And we're starting with Justice Rehnquist.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Back then confirmation hearings were usually brief and tamed affairs.

utterances.speaker: FELDMAN
utterances.sentences: If you were a competent judge capable of being a functioning justice, you would get confirmed.

utterances.speaker: SEVERINO
utterances.sentences: The Bork confirmation changed that.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED PROTESTER
utterances.sentences: Judge Bork should be immediately confirmed.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The right thought Bork would be a shoe-in. He was a distinguished scholar and an appeals court judge.

utterances.speaker: SEVERINO
utterances.sentences: So well respected and thought of in the legal academy, there'd be no problem getting him confirmed.

utterances.speaker: FELDMAN
utterances.sentences: Liberals were appropriately worried about what Robert Bork would do if he got on the Supreme Court.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Among his views, he was against the 1964 Civil Rights Act.SEN. TED KENNEDY (D-MA): Blacks would sit at segregated lunch counters.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Ted Kennedy led the charge against Bork.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.sentences: Robert Bork's America is a land in which women would be forced into back alley abortions.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The women's groups frankly are afraid. They're afraid of you. ZAKARIAsterilization order for women who wanted to work at a chemical plant.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE ROBERT BORK, FORMER SUPREME COURT JUSTICE NOMINEE
utterances.sentences: I supposed the five women who chose to stay on the job -- on that job with higher pay and chose sterilization, I supposed that they were glad to have the choice.SEN. JOE BIDEN (D-DE): Those in favor of the Bork nomination will vote aye. Those opposed will vote no.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: A young Joe Biden, then chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, called for a vote.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Bird?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Metzenbaum?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The no's won. Republicans were furious.SEN. JOHN DANFORTH (R-MO): Let this trashing go on and let this good man be characterized as some sort of Frankenstein's monster without raising a voice against it. All of us are accomplices.

utterances.speaker: TOTENBERG
utterances.sentences: Those hearings became sort of the battle cry of the Republican Party after that.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Nina Totenberg has been a Supreme Court reporter for 50 years.

utterances.speaker: TOTENBERG
utterances.sentences: Republicans definitely believe that Democrats started this. Now that they did this to Bork, we're going to Bork everybody else.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: A young senator from Kentucky had the last word.SEN. MITCH MCCONNELL (R-KY): So to Robert Bork, you fought the good fight. You happen to be the one who set the new Senate standard that will be applied in my judgment by a majority of the Senate prospectively. Unfortunately, it got set over your dead body so to speak.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: He essentially said you will rue the day.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And he was right.JUSTICE CLARENCE THOMAS, U.S. SUPREME COURT: This is a circus. This is a national disgrace. It is a high-tech lynching for uppity blacks.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The circus hearing has become a repeated ritual.

utterances.speaker: KAVANAUGH
utterances.sentences: That is a farce.SEN. ORRIN HATCH (R-UT): I think it would be the greatest travesty I've ever seen in the nomination process.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The more corrosive the hearings grew, the more America's trust in the court collapsed.How did we get here? To really understand the roots of it, we need to go still further back to what may just be the most consequential moment in Supreme Court history. The early 1950s, the post-war boom. But for many, the American dream was only available if you were white. Segregation had an iron grip on the south.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We had absolutely no intention of integrating in the South.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: For the Brown family of Topeka Kansas, separate but equal meant their daughter could not attend her neighborhood school. The Supreme Court heard the case of "Brown versus the Board of Education." Like America itself, the court was bitterly divided over separate but equal.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Separate educational facilities are inherently unequal.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: A new chief justice was determined to change that. Earl Warren knew that a ruling in favor of "Brown" would not be enforceable unless it was unanimous.

utterances.speaker: TOTENBERG
utterances.sentences: Chief Justice Warren was a great master of trying to bring the court together.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: He argued and cajoled for months. Finally he got every judge to agree. The court ruled for "Brown" 9-0.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Since May 17th, 1954, America has never been quite the same.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It was to me the Magna Carta. It was the second Emancipation.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: It was the beginning of the Warren court. A revolutionary judicial era that would change the fabric of American life.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: The court under Earl Warren just opened up America in so many different ways.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: It was in a sense today's court in reverse.

utterances.speaker: TOTENBERG
utterances.sentences: Conservatives used to castigate the liberal Warren court as being activist.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: It issued dozens of rulings that enraged conservatives.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: History-making decisions.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Some enhanced the rights of criminal defendants. BISKUPICa right to have a lawyer present when you're questioned.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED PROTESTERS
utterances.sentences: Impeach Earl Warren.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Impeach Earl Warren. When Earl Warren finally retired in 1969, conservatives believed they might finally get their chance to change the court. But it would be another 40 years. A long, political battle, for power and money, before the right would get the court it dreamed of.(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: A bombshell decision by the U.S. Supreme Court.

utterances.speaker: FREDRICKA WHITFIELD, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: The court could target other landmark precedent.

utterances.speaker: PAMELA BROWN, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: The Supreme Court's most life-changing ruling in decades.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: 2022 has been a year of high drama at the Supreme Court.

utterances.speaker: SCHNEIDER
utterances.sentences: Made possible by a conservative supermajority.

utterances.speaker: BRIANNA KEILAR, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: The conservative majority of justices.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Reverses nearly 50 years --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: -- of interpreting the Constitution.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The Supreme Court in the last two years --

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But America has been here before.FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT, 32ND PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We want a Supreme Court which will do justice under the Constitution. Not over it.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The epic knockdown constitutional brawl.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The political bombshell that divides the nation.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The attacks of the Supreme Court.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Of the 1930s. Hard-right Supreme Court justices.

utterances.speaker: ROOSEVELT
utterances.sentences: We cannot yield to the personal judgement of a few men fearful of the future. ZAKARIA

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The NRA.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The rallies around the blue eagle.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: New deal suffered massive damage from the Supreme Court.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Killing popular, bipartisan laws like no court before. Laws meant to save a nation from collapse.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: $30 billion in stock value vanished.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Grim, bleak, hopeless and helpless.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The conservative justices were known as the "Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse."

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Die-hard conservatives among the Supreme Court --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Struck down the Agricultural Adjustment Act and Municipal Bankruptcy Act.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The New York Minimum Wage Law.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Theirs is the last word.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And their story carries warnings for today.

utterances.speaker: ROOSEVELT
utterances.sentences: If we would make democracy succeed, we must act now.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It was the beginning of the worst calamity the United States economy had ever known.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: It was the height of the Great Depression.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Banks closed, millions were put out of work.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The stock market had plummeted 90 percent.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Despair, a sense of helplessness, a sense of hopelessness.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: A quarter of the country was unemployed.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Makes his bid to become dictator of America. Can't happen here, the saying goes. But it seems to be.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And political extremism was threatening democracy.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Communists became violent, taking advantage of the depression, general unemployment.

utterances.speaker: TOTENBERG
utterances.sentences: This whole country was in danger of going under.

utterances.speaker: ROOSEVELT
utterances.sentences: This is a call to arms. To restore America to its own people.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: A frightened people turns hopefully toward a new national leader. His campaign promise, a new deal.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: A nation that needed saving.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The inauguration of Franklin Delano Roosevelt.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Elected Franklin Delano Roosevelt in a landslide.

utterances.speaker: ROOSEVELT
utterances.sentences: This nation is asking for action.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Hoping his activist government policies would rescue the country.

utterances.speaker: ROOSEVELT
utterances.sentences: The only thing we have to fear is fear itself.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: In his first 100 days, he delivered.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Bill after bill poised into Congress.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Fifteen bills with far-reaching significance.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: With the most ambitious legislative agenda in history, the New Deal.

utterances.speaker: ROOSEVELT
utterances.sentences: We can put people back to work.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Creating vast federal programs to get Americans back on their feet.

utterances.speaker: ROOSEVELT
utterances.sentences: You people must have faith. Together, we cannot fail.

utterances.speaker: TOTENBERG
utterances.sentences: They were going to try almost everything and anything to try to get this country stood up again and working. And they did.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But the president had a big problem. The Supreme Court was killing his laws at a record pace. Ten times more often than previous courts.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Vital pieces of New Deal legislation are unconstitutional.

utterances.speaker: FELDMAN
utterances.sentences: The Supreme Court of the United States was controlled by a conservative indeed libertarian property-protecting majority.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The court had killed almost any law that tried to regulate the economy. Like minimum wage laws.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Half a million children are working as low-paid day laborers. ZAKARIA

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The formation of the entire New Deal program are rocked.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: In quick succession, the Supreme Court invalidated law after law.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The court dealt three huge blows to the New Deal in one day.

utterances.speaker: FELDMAN
utterances.sentences: Major pieces of legislation passed by an overwhelming majority of Congress as the solution to the depression.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Americans were livid with the court. Hanging justices in effigy. One justice referred to the Great Depression as a temporary inconvenience.

utterances.speaker: TOTENBERG
utterances.sentences: This is a conservative majority that really didn't care about the little guy.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It's Roosevelt again.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Roosevelt takes every state in the union.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: By the largest majority in history.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: In 1936, the nation responded.

utterances.speaker: ROOSEVELT
utterances.sentences: I will faithfully execute --

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Re-electing FDR with more than 60 percent of the vote.

utterances.speaker: ROOSEVELT
utterances.sentences: We can now march forward all of us together.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But the New Deal still appeared to be doomed.

utterances.speaker: ROOSEVELT
utterances.sentences: We must take action to save the Constitution from the court.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: So Roosevelt declared war on the court.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: He tried to enlarge the court with justices of his own choosing.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Shocking Congress with a bombshell bill.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Opponents denounce it as court packing.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: That would add as many as six new justices chosen by him.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: What he proposed is for every justice who is over age 70, and it was the older justices who were causing him so much trouble, he would be able to appoint a new justice.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I am opposed to packing the court.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: There was bipartisan outrage over the bill.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: This is the road to autocracy.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Even accusations of fascism.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: He horrified a lot of people, some of them calling him a dictator.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But the president's plan was perfectly constitutional.

utterances.speaker: FELDMAN
utterances.sentences: The Constitution actually never says that there have to be nine justices.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The number of justices have changed many times. Starting at six in 1789. Then five, reaching 10 at one point, before settling on nine. The court was very weak in the early days of the republic. Some of its rulings were openly defied.

utterances.speaker: FELDMAN
utterances.sentences: President Andrew Jackson, after an opinion he didn't like, is reputed to have said, Chief Justice Marshall has made his decision, now let him enforce it. And then Jackson just ignored the Supreme Court.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But over the years, the court had gained enormous power. And now it was using that power to block progress at FDR.

utterances.speaker: ROOSEVELT
utterances.sentences: We have only just begun to fight.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The president and Congress --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The greatest political sweep in history.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Despite their overwhelming election victories --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The stock market crashed.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: -- could do virtually nothing to fight the depression.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: From 61 percent of the American public came a definite answer.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The clash over court packing riveted the nation.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It is the duty of every citizen to concern himself with this question.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Let's not tamper with it.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: By all means let us make this change.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: It was the greatest political drama of the era.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The Supreme Court captures the headline.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Thousands of letters and telegrams poured into Congress from all over the country.

utterances.speaker: TOTENBERG
utterances.sentences: It was one of the great legislative battles of all time. The majority leader had a heart attack and died in the middle of it.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I believe the people are entitled to new judges and should have them now.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: FDR's plan seemed almost certain to pass Congress.

utterances.speaker: ROOSEVELT
utterances.sentences: Great majorities have approved what we are trying to do.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And the court would soon number 15 justices. Then suddenly, the Supreme Court blinked.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The Supreme Court upholds the Wagner Act.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: It completely changed its view in three seismic cases. Upholding the Minimum Wage Law. An important labor law. And the Social Security Act.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Holding the balance of power at 61, the youngest doctor.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The court's swing vote, Justice Owen Roberts, who had sided with the conservatives, swung over to the liberals. With the New Deal laws upheld, court packing seemed unnecessary.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The senate of the United States gave the most popular president of the 20th Century his worst political defeat.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And was soundly defeated in Congress.

utterances.speaker: FELDMAN
utterances.sentences: It was a switch by one justice that saved the court from being packed. And observers call that the switch in time that saved nine.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Is there a justice on today's court that could have a similar change of heart? And move the court closer to the views of most Americans? Possibly court insiders say, but don't count on it.

utterances.speaker: SUNLEN SERFATY, CNN WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Eroding the barrier between church and state.ZAKARIA (voice-over): For those shocked by the Supreme Court's last term, court watchers have a piece of advice -- strap yourself in.

utterances.speaker: TOTENBERG
utterances.sentences: It's going to be a very bumpy ride.

utterances.speaker: FELDMAN
utterances.sentences: Fundamental rights are back on the table.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: More bombshells could be coming. And more rights could disappear. In his concurring opinion overturning Roe v. Wade, Justice Clarence Thomas signaled his desire to keep going.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: Clarence Thomas wrote so many other things should be up for grabs.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: He called on the court to reconsider the right to contraception, gay marriage, even same-sex intimacy. Liberals may not like it, but there is a certain logic to the Thomas argument. Like Roe, those rights were all based on what previous courts saw as a constitutional right to privacy. Strike down that foundation, and the other rights fall with it. In a separate concurrence, Justice Kavanaugh said the court was not opening the door to eliminating other rights.

utterances.speaker: FELDMAN
utterances.sentences: He bent over backwards to say this is only about abortion.

utterances.speaker: FELDMAN
utterances.sentences: A good example here would be the Newark state gun law more than a century old.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: It doesn't end there. America's long standing system of governance is under fire. For nearly 100 years, Congress has passed sweeping laws empowering federal agencies, like the EPA, the FDA, and others, to create rules that keep Americans safe.

utterances.speaker: FELDMAN
utterances.sentences: Agencies have expertise. It's up to the agency to interpret ambiguous statutes in the light of the agency's expert knowledge.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But last term, the Supreme Court said, not so fast. The court struck down a rule from the Environmental Protection Agency aimed at reducing carbon emissions from power plants. The rule could have helped blunt the ravages of global warming.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: The United States, ravaged by wildfires.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The worst drought in centuries. BLITZER

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: If the court keeps ruling in this direction, it could strike down thousands of other regulations created by federal agencies under broad congressional statutes. Basic rules that protect consumers, patients, workers, could all be upended. Congress would have to pass hundreds of new laws to address every possible application of its intentions. That will never happen, of course, which hands even more power to the justices.

utterances.speaker: FELDMAN
utterances.sentences: The court effectively said to the rest of the political system, we are the last word, we are in charge.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And then there's the biggest case you've never heard of.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: A legal theory headed to the Supreme Court.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: That worries scholars from across the political spectrum.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: It could literally upend democracy.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: This term, the Supreme Court will rule on the so-called Independent State Legislature Theory. Partisan state legislatures may soon have complete control over federal elections.

utterances.speaker: PAUL BEGALA, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST
utterances.sentences: That's dictatorship. That's madness.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The theory isn't new. It dates back more than 20 years. To another monumental case.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Nine justices, as divided as this nation.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Bush versus Gore saw five conservative justices essentially hand the presidency over to George W. Bush.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Please raise your right hand and repeat after me.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Most of the justices seemed unconvinced by the court's own decision. They suggested the opinion was limited just to this one unusual case. Even after voting with the majority, Justice Antonin Scalia called the opinion -- pardon my language but I am quoting here -- a piece of shit.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: The opinion itself was only cited one time by a Supreme Court justice.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: That is, until 2020.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: We're going to defeat sleepy Joe Biden.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: As Donald Trump faced off against Biden, Republicans began dusting off an obscure argument from the once pariah case "Bush v. Gore." The independent state legislature theory.Chief Justice Rehnquist claimed the Constitution gave state legislatures complete control over presidential elections. Today, some Republicans want that unchecked power over all federal elections. (On-camera): To put it very simply, state legislatures can do whatever they want, and state courts, even the state's Supreme Court has no authority to say what you're doing violates the state constitution.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: And what makes this so poignant is that right now in America, most of the state legislatures are controlled by Republicans.ZAKARIA (voice-over): Six of Rehnquist's fellow justices rejected the theory. But this court has seen four conservatives already voice some support. If the theory stands, election experts predict chaos in any close contest, with legislatures questioning the results and maybe even selecting their own electors.

utterances.speaker: FELDMAN
utterances.sentences: Imagine it's 2024. The presidential election is so close that it all comes down to one state, let's say Pennsylvania.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Pennsylvania's voters choose the Democrat. But the Republican dominated legislature claims fraud and awards the state to their candidate.

utterances.speaker: FELDMAN
utterances.sentences: So now the president of the United States is going to be the Republican candidate.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Even though they actually lost the election. Democrats appeal to the highest court in the land.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The Republican enters the White House. The loser becomes the winner.

utterances.speaker: FELDMAN
utterances.sentences: That would be a constitutional travesty.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Not everyone agrees the theory can lead to a stolen election.ELIZA SWEREN-BECKER, COUNSEL, BRENNAN CENTER: Federal law prohibits state legislatures from overturning the results of elections.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The federal government could rein in a runaway state legislature, but who can predict what this Supreme Court would decide? With a supermajority anchored by three of its youngest and most ideological members, this court does have the chance to rewrite life in America.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: These people will affect our lives, our children's lives, probably our grandchildren's lives.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: As with the last term's abortion decision, the future may rest in the hands of one justice in particular. FELDMAN
